evidence.text:
Person B: Hey, Berniece. Doaker said you was sleep. I said at least you could get up and say hi.
Person B: Hell, I ain’t done nothing but come in and say hi. I ain’t got in the house good. I come eighteen hundred miles to see my sister I figure she might want to get up and say hi. What you got, Doaker? Where your bottle? Me and Lymon want a drink. This is Lymon. You remember Lymon Jackson from down home.

Person A: They can come over and join the party. We fixing to have a party. Doaker, where your bottle? Me and Lymon celebrating. The Ghosts of the Yellow Dog got Sutter.
Person A: Ask Lymon, they found him the next morning. Say he drowned in his well.
Person B: I told you it’s Lymon’s. Doaker, where your bottle? I know you got a bottle stuck up in your room. Come on, me and Lymon want a drink.

Person A: What the sheriff looking for you for, Lymon?
Person B: The man don’t want you to know all his business. He’s my company. He ain’t asking you no questions.

Person B: I was fixing to get her now. Hey, Maretha! Maretha!
Person B: You going up there...wake her up and tell her her uncle’s here. I ain’t seen her in three years.

Person A: Don’t you wake that child up!
Person A: I ain’t waking that child up...and don’t you be making all that noise.
Person B: That’s all in Berniece’s head. Ain’t nobody up there. Go on up there, Doaker.

Person B: What he look like?
Person B: Sutter couldn’t find his way from Big Sandy to Little Sandy. How he gonna find his way all the way up here to Pittsburgh? Sutter ain’t never even heard of Pittsburgh.

Person A: He bending over looking down his well, woman...how he know who pushed him? It could have been anybody. Where was you when Sutter fell in his well? Where was Doaker? Me and Lymon was over in Stoner County. Tell her, Lymon. The Ghosts of the Yellow Dog got Sutter. That’s what happened to him.
Person B: You can talk all that Ghosts of the Yellow Dog stuff if you want. I know better.

Person A: Boy Willie, I want you and Lymon to go ahead and leave my house. Just go on somewhere. You don’t do nothing but bring trouble with you everywhere you go. If it wasn’t for you Crawley would still be alive.
Person A: I want you and Lymon to go on and take all this confusion out of my house!

Person A: Come on, Doaker, walk up here with me. Let me get Maretha up and get her started. I got to get ready myself. Boy Willie, just go on out there and sell them watermelons and you and Lymon leave my house.
Person A: Maretha, run back upstairs and get my pocketbook. And wipe that hair grease off your forehead. Go ahead, hurry up.
Person A: How you doing, Avery? You done got all dressed up. You look nice. Boy Willie, I thought you and Lymon was going to sell them watermelons.
Person B: Doaker. I’m gonna stop down there on Logan Street. You want anything?
Person B: I knew it. I knew it when I first seen you. I knew you was up to something.

Person B: I ain’t selling that piano, Boy Willie. If that’s why you come up here you can forget about it. Doaker, I’ll see you later. Boy Willie ain’t nothing but a whole lot of mouth. I ain’t paying him no mind. If he come up here thinking he gonna sell that piano then he done come up here for nothing.

Person B: I don’t want to go through none of your stuff. I done told you to go back where you belong.
Person B: Wining Boy, when you get here?
Person A: You ain’t cooked me nothing when I come.
Person B: Boy Willie, go on and leave me alone. Come on, Maretha, get up here and change your clothes before you get them dirty.

Person A: Look at this piano. Look at it. Mama Ola polished this piano with her tears for seventeen years. For seventeen years she rubbed on it till her hands bled. Then she rubbed the blood in...mixed it up with the rest of the blood on it. Every day that God breathed life into her body she rubbed and cleaned and polished and prayed over it. “Play something for me, Berniece. Play something for me, Berniece.” Every day. “I cleaned it up for you, play something for me, Berniece.” You always talking about your daddy but you ain’t never stopped to look at what his foolishness cost your mama. Seventeen years’ worth of cold nights and an empty bed. For what? For a piano? For a piece of wood? To get even with somebody? I look at you and you’re all the same. You, Papa Boy Charles, Wining Boy, Doaker, Crawley...you’re all alike. All this thieving and killing and thieving and killing. And what it ever lead to? More killing and more thieving. I ain’t never seen it come to nothing. People getting burned up. People getting shot. People falling down their wells. It don’t never stop.

Person B: See, that’s ignorant. That’s downright foolish for you to say something like that. You ain’t doing nothing but showing your ignorance. If the nigger was here I’d whup his ass for getting me and Lymon shot at.

Person B: We told the man about the wood. Ask Lymon. He knew all about the wood. He seen we was sneaking it. Why else we gonna be out there at night? Don’t come telling me Crawley ain’t knew about the wood. Them fellows come up on us and Crawley tried to bully them. Me and Lymon seen the sheriff with them and give in. Wasn’t no sense in getting killed over fifty dollars’ worth of wood.

Person A: All I know is Crawley would be alive if you hadn’t come up there and got him.
Person A: Crawley’s dead and in the ground and you still walking around here eating. That’s all I know. He went off to load some wood with you and ain’t never come back.
Person A: Come on now, Berniece...don’t do this now. Doaker, get her.
Person A: I done told you now. Doaker, get her. I ain’t playing.

Person A: I ain’t in you’ house. I’m in Doaker’s house. If he ask me to leave then I’ll go on and leave. But consider me done left your part.
Person B: Doaker, tell him to leave. Tell him to go on.
Person B: Carry it out of here just as big and bold. Do like my daddy would have done come time to get Sutter’s land.

Person B: She trying to scare me. Hell, I ain’t scared of dying. I look around and see people dying every day. You got to die to make room for somebody else. I had a dog that died. Wasn’t nothing but a puppy. I picked it up and put it in a bag and carried it up there to Reverend C.L. Thompson’s church. I carried it up there and prayed and asked Jesus to make it live like he did the man in the Bible. I prayed real hard. Knelt down and everything. Say ask in Jesus’ name. Well, I must have called Jesus’ name two hundred times.
Person A: That’s why I don’t talk to him, Doaker. You try and talk to him and that’s the only kind of stuff that comes out his mouth.

Person A: Be still, Maretha. If you was a boy I wouldn’t be going through this.
Person A: You ain’t got nothing to do with this child.
Person A: Boy Willie, go on and leave me alone.

Person A: Let me take care of my child. When you get one of your own then you can teach it what you want to teach it.
Person B: Hey, Doaker...Berniece say the colored folks is living at the bottom of life. You think you living at the bottom of life? Is that how you see yourself?

Person B: See now...I’ll tell you something about me. I done strung along and strung along. Going this way and that. Whatever way would lead me to a moment of peace. That’s all I want. To be easy with everything. But I wasn’t born to that. I was born to a time of fire. The world ain’t wanted no part of me. I could see that since I was about seven. The world say it’s better off without me. See, Berniece accept that. She trying to come up to where she can prove something to the world. Hell, the world a better place ‘cause of me. I don’t see it like Berniece. I got a heart that beats here and it beats just as loud as the next fellow’s. Don’t care if he black or white. Sometime it beats louder. When it beats louder, then everybody can hear it. Some people get scared of that. Like Berniece. Some people get scared to hear a nigger’s heart beating. They think you ought to lay low with that heart. Make it beat quiet and go along with everything the way it is. But my mama ain’t birthed me for nothing. So what I got to do? I got to mark my passing on the road. Just like you write on a tree, “Boy Willie was here.” That’s all I’m trying to do with that piano. Trying to put my mark on the road. Like my daddy done. My heart say for me to sell that piano and get me some land so I can make a life for myself to live in my own way. Other than that I ain’t thinking about nothing Berniece got to say.
Person A: Boy Willie...I done told you to leave me alone.
Person A: You keep messing with me.
Person B: I ain’t thinking about you.
Person A: Boy Willie ain’t taking nothing out of my house but himself. Now you let him go ahead and try.

Person A: I want you to help me/I want you to help me/I want you to help me/Mama Berniece/I want you to help me
Person A: Mama Esther/I want you to help me
Person A: Papa Boy Charles/I want you to help me
Person A: Mama Ola/I want you to help me/I want you to help me
